is a picturesque village on the Gatineau River in the Gatineau Hills near
side of the river but is predominantly English-speaking.

Take any bridge from Ottawa to Hull or Gatineau. There are usually signs that say "Hull". Once in Quebec, the highway will be identified as Highway 5 to Maniwaki. Take Highway 5 North until the end. Then North on Highway 105 until the exit for Wakefield, at which you should make a right turn. It takes about 30-45 minutes depending on the traffic in Ottawa.
goes from the Ottawa bus terminal to Wakefield once per day and takes about 1 hour and 15 minutes. A return ticket is about $15.

value: name=The Black Sheep Inn (Le Mouton Noir)
content=Has become well known for top quality musical entertainment. Check listings in Ottawa Newspapers, such as the Ottawa Citizen or on their web site.
name=Prime Minister Lester B Pearson's Gravesite

content=MacLaren Cemetery, behind the Mill. Turn on Mill Road off of River Road and then turn Right on MacLaren immediately after the Mill. The cemetery is at the top of the hill. A Nobel Peace Prize recipient, former prime minister, and contributor to the founding of the United Nations, Pearson died in 1972.
is an historic bridge that was burned down and reconstructed in 1996. Indicative of the area, the red bridge spans the Gatineau River near the centre of the village.
in the Gatineau Hills are incredible. Usually best in late September and early October, the whole region is a feast for your eyes.

During the spring months, and "break up time", locals place a barrel on the ice of the Gatineau River. Bets are placed as to when this barrel will sink. Nothing spectacular to see, but if you look for it, it will be there.
There are several small shops featuring local artisans and interesting articles.
content=Held in September each year and features many local artists. Visitors can tour the studios of local artists and acquire interesting creative works.

content=As of 2010, was offering (Inter-)active language holidays which combine adult second-language immersion with a holiday adventure. French on a horse or dog sled? English in the canoe or an the greens?
can be accessed from the village and from several other locations nearby. Hiking, walking, snowshoeing, cross-country skiing trails abound.

starting from several points in Wakefield Village will give visitors historical or nature perspectives. Groomed and marked baths run along the outskirts of the Village and can be accessed by MacLaren House, near the Mill.

in the Gatineau River or one of the hundreds of lakes in the area. Rentals can be arranged with Boutique Burro Borracho at 721-B Riverside Dr beside Solstice Books. Canoe trips can also be booked with Expeditions Radisson
content=Ski hill, snow tubing, equipment rental and repair, restaurant and bar on-site.
content=Horse back riding on trails which wrap through the lush forests, open fields and wind through mountainous terrain.
content=Omelettes, soup, bread, jager schnitzel. Casual.
content=Upscale restaurant in village's old train station on Gatineau River. French, Québécois and international cuisine.  Site is the subject of a Philip Craig painting.
content=Dining room, sandbox and patio. Café by day with superb specialty coffees, lunch specials, several innovative dishes and a bistro by night.
content=Gourmet pizza featuring unusual ingredients on a herbed thin crust.

content=Two restaurants in the village's original mill, each with glass-enclosed solariums and views of the La Pêche Falls. The (not inexpensive) fine dining restaurant offers traditional French and Québécois cuisine, table d’hôte menu, six-course Discovery Menu, wine cellar. The Heron Room and bar lounge offers a casual tapas and bistro menu, wine, fish and chips, fireplace and live music.
content=Resto-Bar at the main entrance to the village.
name=Auberge de Mon Petit Chum Bed and Breakfast

content=Downtown 3-room B&B, full breakfast, wi-fi, all rooms have private bath. Coffee, tea & hot chocolate available 24 hours/day. Several packages introduce visitors to local restaurants, Ottawa area museums, outdoor activities, local music venues and spas.
content=Four-sun bed and breakfast close to the centre of the village, attractive barn-style architecture, several rustic rooms, some feature kitchenettes. Regular yoga sessions.
content=Restored mill on the La Pêche River at a small waterfall. Spa and restaurant. Rooms from $109/night, including continental breakfast. Dinner and spa packages available.
content=Four-sun bed and breakfast in the heart of Wakefield village in historic village doctor's residence, constructed in 1896, a beautiful building on lovely grounds.
content=Rustic European-styled motel, 16 rooms, on-site local restaurant.
content=Austrian-style Chalet on Greyhound bus route, near Vorlage Ski Centre. Apartment with wood fireplace & fully equipped kitchen from $89/99.
North along Hwy 105 for about 20km will take you to Low, Quebec. A small town with a hockey arena.
